svcsection.title: AIR CONDITIONING COMPRESSOR AND CLUTCH TWO CYLINDER RECIPROCATING TYPE - BEFORE 01/01/1993 (R-12)

lev1.para: To meet the Federal Government's scheduled phase-out of CFC-12 (R-12) refrigerant, International will start building vehicles charged with the new refrigerant HFC-134A on the following dates:

lev1.title: COMPRESSOR
lev1.para: The compressor is a two-cylinder reciprocating unit ( Figure 1). It is belt driven through a magnetic clutch located on the compressor crankshaft.

lev1.para: The functions of the compressor are to push the refrigerant through the air conditioning system, and compress and superheat the heat-saturated refrigerant returned from the evaporator.

The compressor crankcase, cylinder head, pistons, connecting rods, bearing housing, valve plate and base plate are die cast aluminum. The crankshaft is cast iron as are the cylinder liners, which are permanently cast into the crankcase.

The lubrication system uses the existing pressure differential between the suction intake and the crankcase to provide lubricating oil to bearings and internal components. An oil plug on each side of the crankcase permits oil checking regardless of compressor mounting.

With the introduction of HFC-134A refrigerant, the high pressure relief valve is moved from the receiver-dryer to the compressor on production vehicles ( Figure 1). Replacement receiver-dryers will have a pressure relief valve.

lev1.title: MAGNETIC CLUTCH
lev1.para: The compressor magnetic clutch is secured to the compressor crankshaft ( Figure 2). The purpose of the clutch is to engage and disengage the belt drive as necessary to maintain desired interior cab temperature.

The primary components of the clutch are: the pulley assembly, which contains the clutch disc and bearing and is mounted on the crankshaft, and the stationary field coil, mounted on the compressor housing ( Figure 2).

lev2.title: COMPRESSOR
lev2.para: The compressor is driven by the vehicle engine and operates on demand by the air conditioning system through the magnetic clutch. During the down stroke a slight vacuum is created between the top of the piston and the cylinder head causing the inlet valve to open. Refrigerant at a pressure of 12 to 50 psi is drawn into the cylinder. As the piston begins its upward stroke, the refrigerant that was drawn into the cylinder on the down stroke is being compressed. Pressure on the inlet valve allows it to close. The piston continues its upward stroke and refrigerant now compressed to 120-300 psi pushes the outlet valve open. Refrigerant flows through the open valve into the air conditioning system.

lev2.title: MAGNETIC CLUTCH
lev2.para: During operation, electrical current flows into the field coil. The energized field coil, acting as an electromagnet, holds the clutch plate in contact with the pulley, setting the compressor in motion. When the cab interior reaches the desired temperature, the field coil is de-energized, the clutch plate is released from the pulley, and compressor operation stops.
